author: sky.cactus
content: My current stance is that I don't see a path to ASE that doesn't come with some very serious caveats/gotchas/foot ugns.  I really want ASE, I think it is important for the longterm health of Ethereum, I just don't see a way to get there.

author: .vbuterin
content: And I guess if PBS makes state expiry low-priority then that's fine, ASE is also low-urgency and we can just keep figuring it out slowly

author: potuz
content: Is PBS proposer builder separation? If so, why does it make state expiry low priority?

author: .vbuterin
content: yeah, PBS is proposer builder separation

author: .vbuterin
content: > why does it make state expiry low priority?

author: .vbuterin
content: Because once we have PBS and Verkle trees, validators don't need to store the state

author: .vbuterin
content: Only builders would need to store the state

author: .vbuterin
content: And builders are assumes to be more powerful than other nodes already

author: .vbuterin
content: So it's ok if the state goes up to 1 TB or whatever

author: potuz
content: But this requires data availability so that users can proof the state right?

author: potuz
content: Ahh I see, and you're also assuming Verkle trees.

author: potuz
content: In this regard I think only Verkle trees and proofs are enough: I don't feel any guilt enforcing validators to have a couple TB in disk. The problem I see is how to guarantee that users can have the current chain status without downloading the full node. If we had working light clients I agree that state growth is not that much of a problem
